turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: How certain are you that you haven't been sick in your life?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Seventy-five percent.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Seventy-five percent? That's not nearly good enough for me. I'm extremely skeptical.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Skeptical about what?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Your answer to my question. It's one thing to have never been injured in your life, but to state that you've never taken ill, well that's a whole new level.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: What's he talking about?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: In college. A car accident.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Was it serious?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: I assumed because of the train.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You assumed wrong.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You forgot the "Now I'm going to tell you what the hell is going on" step. See usually that comes before the, "It's over" Step. And it always, always comes before the "You can go" Step.  What is over?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: The life of an idea that has lived too long in my head.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: This city has had its share of disasters. Well publicized ones. It was around the time of that plane crash, when it first entered my head. And there it stayed, as I waited and watched the news over the years...  And then one day I see a news report on a train accident and its sole survivor who was miraculously unharmed.  And just like that, an idea blossoms into the flower of possible reality.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What was your idea Elijah?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: At the church... You were following me weren't you?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Technically no. I gambled that you would attend the church service. I just waited for you.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What's this about? This is obviously some scam. Is this where you tell me one of those pictures is like an investment?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: You've misunderstood.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I see guys like you all the time in my work. You find someone you think is emotionally vulnerable and you tell them a fantastic story, utterly convincing... and somewhere in there, you slip it in... 'I just need your credit card number','I just need a small down payment.'

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: It's for last week's game.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: I've come to understand that...  An ill advised purchase in the parking lot.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Not money.  But I appreciate your healthy cynicism in the manner. It will be wise for both of us to proceed with greatest caution.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: We're not proceeding anywhere together.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: We've already begun.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Why is it, do you think, that of all the professions in the world... you chose protection?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Are you for real?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: You could have poured coffee in Starbucks, you could have learned to install track lighting in office buildings, you could have told people their horoscopes on the internet... You could have been one of ten thousand things... but in the end, you chose to protect people. You made that decision... and I find that very, very interesting.  Now all I need is your credit card number.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Just give me a minute.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Is there a problem?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: That guy in green. Sometimes people carry weapons in here. Then they drink too much. They're team isn't doing so well, bad things happen... We do random pat downs of the crowd to discourage people from carrying.  If he's carrying, he'll step out of line.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I got you a seat in the seven hundred level.  It's nose-bleed territory, but at least you won't get spit on.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: How did you know that man you bumped was carrying a weapon?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Probably the army jacket. Those guys carry hunting knives and stuff for show.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: You thought he was carrying a knife?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I thought he was carrying something.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: But not a knife?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I got this picture of a silver handled gun tucked in his pants.  Like on t.v.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: You have good instincts when it comes to things like that?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Telling when people have done something wrong?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Have you ever tried to develop it?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't know what you're asking?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: You're skill.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Listen. I got to be on the sidelines during the game... You can get to your seat by taking the stairwell at--

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Characters in comic books are often attributed special powers. X-ray vision, things of that sort.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Okay, I don't want to play this game anymore.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: It's an exaggeration of the truth. Maybe it's based on something as simple as instinct. Like being able to touch someone and tell whether they've done something wrong... Or the level of what they've done wrong.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: The guy might not have been carrying anything.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Or he might have been carrying a silver handled gun tucked in his pants.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I have to go now.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: One last question.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Quick.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: The car accident you were in... Was there anyone else involved?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I must have felt some lump in his back when I bumped him. Most guns have a black or silver handle. I had a fifty-fifty shot at the color.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: That's not what I witnessed David.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Stop messing with my life Elijah. My son almost shot me last night. He wanted to prove you were right.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: I never said you couldn't be killed. I never said that.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You have a problem, Elijah. My wife is right. Somewhere along the line one of your bones broke and your mind just broke with it.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Are you finished?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No. And I have been sick. I spent a week in a hospital when I was a boy recovering from pneumonia and almost drowning. Two skinny eight year old kids were playing around the pool. They were dunking me. I swallowed water. They didn't know it and they almost killed me.  Heroes don't get killed like that. Normal people do.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: I am. I'm helping him with the sale.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: It's a pleasure to meet you. I'm David Dunne.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: He's spoken of you. He says you're becoming friends.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: We are.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: He's doing well today.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: I'm very proud of him.  He's been through a lot in his life. A lot of ups and downs, a lot of bad spells. A couple I'd thought had broken him... I mean emotionally.  They were bad... But he made it. Yes he did.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: He's kind of a miracle.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: Yes he is.

turns.speaker: WALKIE
turns.text: Dunne, it's Jenkins, we got a guy at gate 17C with a bogus ticket. Says he knows you. He won't tell me his name.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What's he look like?

turns.speaker: WALKIE
turns.text: He's got the most beautiful eyes... The hell kind of question is that? He's a guy.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Send him packing. I'm not walking all the way over there.

turns.speaker: WALKIE
turns.text: Consider him packed. I didn't like his attitude... Struttin around with a cane and shit.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: WALKIE
turns.text: There's a message for you at the office. Your kid was hurt.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: WALKIE
turns.text: Just now. They want you to come down to his school.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Jeremy, why don't you go sleep with your mom?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I want to sleep here tonight.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I think it's be better if I was alone.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I won't make any noise.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: How about your room then? If you get scared like before, you can come back in here?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: He going pro in the draft. They say he can run the fifty--

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: In under six seconds.  I've heard.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm going to go in.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Just play one set of downs. I told them you were great.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Why'd you do that?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Just one--

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Jeremy.  I'm going in. I have to do some things.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: What things?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm going to work out.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I'll help you.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: There's nothing to do.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You think you could beat up Mike Tyson? I mean before he started wiggin out and eating people's ears?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: What if you worked out everyday for six months? You think you could beat him then?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: What if you only ate foods that were good for you and you worked out everyday for a year?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You put too much. That's two hundred and fifty pounds.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: How much can you lift?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I mean if you knew karate?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No Jeremy.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: What if he wasn't aloud to kick and you were really mad at him?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: How much did you take off?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I lied.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: How much is it?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Two hundred and seventy.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What do you do if something happens?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Get mom.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: How many did you put on that time?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: All of it.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: There's no more left?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I'm sleeping in my room.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I'm not scared.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: That's great.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Do you know why?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I know now.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Know what?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You're secret identity.  That man was right.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: YOU WON'T GET HURT...

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Elijah was wrong.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: That was me they were talking about. I almost died. That was me.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You're lying.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm not. I just didn't connect it.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I'll just shoot him once.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Jeremy listen to what--

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Don't be scared.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Jeremy if you pull that trigger I'm going to leave! I'm going to go to New York.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You like sports?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: It's my field. I represent athletes. I'm an agent.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What a coincidence? I'm a male synchronized swimmer and I'm looking for representation.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Is that right?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: But I'm afraid of water, so that's been holding my career back a little bit.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You represent someone in Philadelphia?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I'm meeting a player from Temple University. He's a cornerback. You like football?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: This kid is six foot two, two hundred and forty pounds. He runs the fifty in under six seconds. He's going to be a God.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yeah, hello.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Is David Dunne there?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: He doesn't look very threatening.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: That's what I said to my son. He said, there's always two kinds. The soldier villain who fights the hero with his hands, and then there's the real threat. The brilliant and evil arch enemy who fights the hero with his mind.

turns.speaker: MAN IN SCRUBS
turns.text: How are you feeling?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MAN IN SCRUBS
turns.text: You are in the emergency room of the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. You were in a serious accident.  How's your vision?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: MAN IN SCRUBS
turns.text: Where were you sitting on the train?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Against a window.

turns.speaker: MAN IN SCRUBS
turns.text: In the passenger car?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yes. Where are the rest of the passengers?

turns.speaker: MAN IN SCRUBS
turns.text: Was your family traveling with you?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MAN IN SCRUBS
turns.text: Did you get up from your seat?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: We're going to prevent any substantial atrophy of your good leg with this.  It works the quadriceps.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: How long have you been married?

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: Twelve years.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: How did you get together?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Now you're going to have to tell me more.

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: ...See my husband was a big football star in college and we were in an accident together. Our car flipped on an icy road. We were both injured. He couldn't play football anymore.  If that hadn't happened, we wouldn't have been together.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: How so?

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: Football wasn't the kind of life I wanted... For ten years I'd be by the phone waiting for a call telling me he broke his neck in a practice game. And if it wasn't that call, it would be a call telling me he blew out his knee or suffered his third concussion. I've seen way too much of it in my job... I can barely take it when my clients are in pain.  I don't hate the game. I admire the amount of skill it involved and, like everyone else, I was in awe of how he could play it, but I couldn't give him my heart and then have something happen to him. And it always does with that game.  It's not a thing many people would understand.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: You and my mother would have a special connection.

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: Any way, fate stepped in and took football out of the equation.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: ...And everyone lived happily ever after.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: There have been three major disasters in this city over the last four years. I've followed each one of them... A Seven-three-seven crashes on take off. One hundred and seventy-two die. No survivors... A hotel fire downtown. Two hundred and eleven die. No survivors... And am Amtrak train derails seven and half miles outside of the city. One hundred and thirty one die. One survivor. He is unharmed.  I've spoken with your husband about his survival. I suggested a rather unbelievable explanation. Since then, I've come to believe, that my explanation, however unbelievable, is in fact, true.

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: And what was that explanation?

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: Is this a religious thing?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: I own a comic book museum. It's called the Limited Edition.

turns.speaker: MEGAN
turns.text: For a second there I thought you were a fanatic.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: I believe comic books are based loosely on reality -- I believe there are real life equivalents of the heroes in those books that walk the earth -- I believe your husband is one of those individuals.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: No more sitting in this room. I've let it go on long enough.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: I'm not going out anymore. I'm not getting hurt again. This was the last time. I told you.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: You can't do anything about that. You might fall between that chair and this television. If that's what God has planned for you, that's what's going to happen. You can't hide from it in your room.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: ...I got a present for you.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: Forget why. Do you want it or not?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: Well, go get it then.

turns.speaker: ELIJAH
turns.text: Where is it?

turns.speaker: ELIJAH'S MOTHER
turns.text: On a bench, across the street.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: She's gonna live.  She didn't steal nothin', She didn't touch his poke.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: All she done was... when she seen he had a teensy little pecker... she gave a giggle. That's all. She didn't know no better.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: A whippin'? That's all they get? After what they done?

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Whippin' ain't a little thing, Alice.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: But what they done, they...

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You... you ain't even gonna... whip 'em?

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: I fined 'em instead.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: For what they done? Skinny gets some ponies an' that's...?

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Ain't you seen enough blood for one night? Hell, Alice, they ain't loafers nor tramps nor bad men. They're hard workin' boys that was foolish. Why if they was given over to wickedness in a regular way...

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Like whores?

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: If they was just here for the fuckin', how come they lit out the back window?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: On account of they seen you was beatin' on their friend.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You just kicked the shit out of a innocent man, you big asshole.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Innocent of what?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Where'd you get the money, huh?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: We ain't got it. We ain't got no money.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: You told them cowboys you had it.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: We was... lyin'.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: What you gonna do when somebody comes to collect?  FUCK 'EM? FUCK 'EM A THOUSAND TIMES?  The kind of people who'll come after that thousand, they won't tolerate if you don't have it. They won't just cut your face up a little.  STUPID CUNTS!

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Rain's coming.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Thank God.

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: I didn't think they'd really do it.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What did you think, they come clear up from Kansas to fuck us?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: That Kid... he's just a... boy. And that other one, Bill, being true to his wife...

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What wife? He don't have no wife.

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: He said...

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I told you, he don't have no wife, not aboveground, anyhow.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Why, if you were to point a pistol at a King or a Queen, sir, I can assure you your hand would shake as though palsied...

turns.speaker: BARBER
turns.text: I wouldn't point no pistol at nobody, sir.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: A wise policy. But if you did, I can assure you, the sight of royalty would cause you to dismiss all thoughts of bloodshed and stand... in awe.  Whereas, a president... I mean, why not shoot a president?

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Now this Strawberry Alice person, tell me again.

turns.speaker: BARBER
turns.text: Down the street and across. Greely's Beer Garden and Billiard parlor. Just ask for Alice and say you want a game of billiards.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Billiards, eh? Even though I don't really wish to play?

turns.speaker: BARBER
turns.text: Don't matter. They burned the table in '78 for firewood.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Ah, I see.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Where's Little Bill for Christ sake?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Ha. He was building his fucking porch.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Building his porch!

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: He's coming ain't he?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: 'Course he's coming.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: What'd he say?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Little Bill? He didn't say nothing. Like I said, he was buildin' his porch. Have you seen that thing?

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: He didn't say nothin', huh?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Asked what they looked like, that's all. Christ, maybe he's tough but he sure ain't no carpenter.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Maybe he ain't so tough.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: We never seen him up against any... like these ones... killers.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Little Bill come out of Kansas an' Texas, boys. He worked them tough towns.

turns.speaker: CHARLEY
turns.text: Just wondered. Anybody could be scared.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: ...wouldn't let you settle it, huh?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Hell, you know how Skinny is. Says he's gonna shoot 'em... an I says, "Skinny, you can't do that," an' he says, "Well, then get Little Bill down here an' let's settle this" an' I says, "Bill's sleepin', Skinny," an'...

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: I couldn't find no bullwhips, Bill. The German...

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Don't matter, we don't need no whips.  Spring comes an' Skinny don't have them ponies, I'm gonna...

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: He tell you where them others is?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: He give 'em names?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Didn't give us nothin' but his own name... Ned Roundtree.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Well, Ned, you'll want to tell me an' Mister Beauchamp here all about them two villainous friends of yours, I guess.  Bring him in, boys, for I will be glad to know the names and the whereabouts of those other two murdering sonsofbitches.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: I thought... you was an angel.

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: You ain't dead.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Some big guy beat the shit out of me.  I guess I must look a lot like you, huh?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: You don't look nothin' like me, mister.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: I didn't mean no offense.  I guess you're the one them cowboys cut up.  Ned an' The Kid, my partners, are they... ?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: They went out scouting when they saw your fever broke.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Scouting?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: On the Bar T... looking for... them.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Oh. How long I been here?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: Three days. Are you hungry?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Three days? I must be.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: I thought I was gone. See them birds? Most times I wouldn't even notice them birds much. But I'm noticin' 'em real good 'cause I thought I was dead.

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: I brought your hat. You... left it down at Greely's.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: That big guy lookin' for me?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: Are you really going to kill them?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Yeah, I guess.  There's still a payment, ain't there?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: Them other two, they been takin' advances on the payment.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Advances?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Free ones?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: Alice an' Silky gave them... free ones.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Oh. Yeah.

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: You want... a free one.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Me? No. No, I guess not.

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: I didn't mean... with me. Alice and Silky, they'll give you one... if you want.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: I... I guess not.  I didn't mean I didn't want one 'cause of you bein' cut up. I didn't mean that.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: You're a beautiful woman an'... if I was to want a free one, I guess I'd want you more than them others. It ain't... See... I can't have no free one on account of my wife...

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: Your wife?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Yeah. See?

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: I admire that, you being true to your wife. I've seen a lot of... of men... who weren't.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Yeah, I guess.

turns.speaker: DELILAH
turns.text: She back in Kansas?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Uh... yeah. Yeah. She's uh... watchin' over the little ones.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Hullo, Bob. Boys, this here is English Bob.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Shit and fried eggs.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Been a long time, Bob. You run out of Chinamen?

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Little Bill, I thought you were dead. I see you shaved off your chin whiskers.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Well, I was always tasting the soup two hours after I et it.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: What I heard was that you fell off your horse drunk and broke your neck.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: I heard that one myself, Bob. Hell, I even thought I was dead til I found out it was just I was in Nebraska.  Who's your friend?

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: WW Beauchamp... Little Bill Daggett and... "friends."

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Books. He's my biographer.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Not really...  Maybe a couple of Peacemakers...  I imagine you could overlook those, eh, Bill? If you didn't see them... or hear them?

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: I guess not, Bob. I don't like guns around.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Charley, see what kind of "books" Mister Beauchamp is packing... but watch you don't get wet.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Be careful with those, sonny.

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: You leave me at the mercy of my enemies.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Enemies, Bob? You been talking about the Queen again? On Independence Day?

turns.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
turns.text: Mmmm pistols.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Oh yeah.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: We got one of them fuckers, Sheriff, out by Cow Creek, we...

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Alive?

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Hell, yeah. A bunch of us Bar T boys went out lookin' on account of them killin' one of our own. We come across this fucker on a roan goin' South an'...

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: He admit it?

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: No... but I guess he will soon enough. Had a Spencer rifle on him an' he was...

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Those cowboys messin' him up?

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Uh... a little, maybe.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: You an' Andy get the hell out there. Find out where them other two went.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Shut up, Alice. Little Bill, a whippin' ain't gonna settle this.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: This here's a lawful contract... betwixt me an' Delilah Fitzgerald, the cut-whore. Now I brung her clear from Boston, paid her expenses an' all, an' I got a contract which represents an investment of capital.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Property.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Damaged property. Like if I was to hamstring one of their cow ponies.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: You figure nobody'll want to fuck her.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Hell no. Leastways, they won't pay to do it.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: She could maybe clean up around the place or somethin', but nobody's gonna pay good money for a cut-up whore.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: You boys are off of the Spade Outfit. Got your own string of ponies?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Hit your finger, huh?

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Huh? Hullo, Skinny. Snuck up on me.  How do you like her?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Heard you done the roof yourself.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Roof? Jesus, Skinny, I done practically every damn thing myself. Roberts boy hauled wood, that's all.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: What's all that wood?

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Porch. I'm puttin' a porch on her so's I can puff my pipe of an evening an' drink my coffee an' watch the sun set.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Them whores, they been fuckin' an' fuckin' all them cowboys that come into town the last two weeks...

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Shit, Skinny, we got railroad barons an' cattle barons, but you' re gonna be the first of the billiard barons.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: ...They been fuckin' 'em, 'an tellin' every bow-legged one of 'em how they're payin' a thousand dollars to whatever sonofabitch kills them two boys which cut up Delilah.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: An' all them cowboys been riding that beef down to Kansas an' Cheyenne?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: All week?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: I didn't hear nothin' till last night.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Word must have got all the way to Texas by now.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Oh, shit, Bill, I guess nobody's gonna come clear from Texas.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: They really got all that money, them whores?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: You know how women kin lie... I knock 'em around a little, ask 'em where the money is, they say they don't have none?... but they coulda squirreled away that much, the five of 'em. Maybe.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: That much, huh?

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: You could run off them two cowboys.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: I could run off them whores.

turns.speaker: SKINNY
turns.text: Well, I guess they'll just up an' run anyhow, them two.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Nope. They'll stay out on the Spade country where they got friends.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Uh, no. No, I ain't drunk.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Ordinance says you got to turn in your firearms to the County office day or night. I guess you didn't read it with the weather an' all.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Well... uh... I... I ain't got no, uh, firearms.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Them friends of yours in the back, they carryin' pistols?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: I... dunno. I mean, I guess not. No, they ain't carryin' no guns.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: You're spillin' your whiskey, mister.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Like I said, I...

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Uh, William... uh... Hendershot.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: Well, Mister Hendershot, if I was to call you a no good sonofabitch an' a liar, an' if I was to say you shit in your pants on account of a cowardly soul... well, I guess then, you would show me your pistol right quick an' shoot me dead, ain't that so?

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: I... I guess I might... but like I said, I ain't armed.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: I guess you just carry it for snakes an' such.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Uh... yeah. Yeah.

turns.speaker: LITTLE BILL
turns.text: There ain't no snakes in here, Mister Hendershot.

turns.speaker: MUNNY
turns.text: Well, uh... it ain't loaded.
